questions.question_text:
During the firmware upgrade of a web server, a power outage occurred. The outage caused a failure within the upgrade.
Which of the following plans must be implemented to revert back to the most recent version of the firmware?

comments.content: Nope. The BACKOUT plan is what would tell you to restore the BIOS from wherever you maintained a copy. (Or how to go get it if you didn't have a local copy.)
They obviously added both of the answers to test students to see if they knew the differences between Back up and Backout plans. Answer is Backup plan.

discussion.content: Unfortunately, this may be a gotcha. Like any firmware update (BIOS/UEFI), any power outage during the update "bricks" the device. There's no backout plan for this as a backout literally means reversing the process which you can't in this specific situation. Instead, you have to now restore from backup (if you have a backup of the BiOS). One can argue, that such BiOS backup is part of a backout plan but technically you're restoring from a backup rather than going in reverse the steps that lead to a failure.

The actual terminology used by compTIA in regards to Change Management is "BACK OUT plan", not "backup plan". This can easily be looked up online (in fact, just about all of this can... that's how I've been verifying these answers). Usually I have a bit of doubt about my thoughts on answers I'm not sure is right, but this one I'm pretty sure is wrong.

Selected Answer: A
The rollback plan, also called the backout plan, describes the steps to roll back from a failed
primary plan. If it were determined that the primary plan could not be completed, you would either implement an alternate (secondary) plan or a rollback plan, depending on the
changes proposed in the change management plan document. Like the primary and alternate plans, the rollback plan should contain the steps to be taken in the event the rollback plan
must be executed. The rollback plan should also document any changes to configuration so
that it can be reverted back. Most of the rollback plan will consist of the original configuration, with any additional steps to revert it back.

Over the years the term backout plan has replaced roll back plan, which was initially the correct answer for this question per Dion's exam. The same question had the option of backup plan or roll back and roll back was correct, therefore I choose back out plan

Selected Answer: A
according to CompTIA a Back out plan would be the correct answer.

The question asks "Which plan must be implimented?". The 'Backup' is part of the BACKOUT PLAN. So the 'Backout' plan must be implemented, which contains the backup.
Which of the following plans must be implemented to ***revert back*** to the most recent version of the firmware? I'm going with Backout plan.

I think the difference is whether or not the work can be finished. A backup plan for if something goes wrong, like a power outage, the system will need to be rolled back to start again. A backout plan is where something is wrong, something which means the work cannot be completed so it is left in the rolled back state.

Backout plan

A backout plan is an IT governance integration approach that specifies the processes required to restore a system to its original or earlier state in the event of failed or aborted implementation. Any installation or upgrade should include a backout plan as part of the change request and change plan. I believe the answer is A. Below is the change management process

1. Determine the scope of the change
2. Analyze the risk associated with the change
3. Create a plan
4. Get end-user approval 
5. Present the proposal to the change control board
6. Have a backout plan if the change doesn't work 
7. Document the changes

questions.question_text:
An office manager emails a technical support contractor about a new desktop for one of the workers. The office manager provides a specific configuration for the desktop. The technician notes the request will require the purchase of a new system. New system purchases are not in the scope of the support agreement.
Which of the following should the technician do NEXT?
Which of the following installation methods will allow a technician to resolve issues that may arise while the installation is being performed?

discussion.content:
1 - Repair Installation (A repair upgrade is the simple process of installing a new build over the existing installation of Windows 7, using your installation DVD. What this does is replace broken operating system files while preserving your personal files, settings and installed applications.)

2 - Image Deployment installation ( Image deployment involves customizing the operating system (OS), applications, drivers and settings on a single computer and creating an image of it, then automatically deploying this image to other computers.)

So if the question is, (solve problems that appear during the installation), why the answer is Image Deployment installation and not repair installation.

comments.content:
Image Deployment resolves problems BEFORE installation thereby preventing potential errors that could occur during installation: Create Image > Test and Resolve > Prepare Image > Deploy
It does not allow for correcting errors during deployment as you have to go back to the first step for changes and updates.

A. Unattended Installation. Uses an image file (answer file) to do mass installations, unattended installations. Where the configuration information is derived from an input file (answerfile.xml)

B. Remote Installation - This is also a part of Unattended Installations. This can be done through PXE boot method. By putting the installation files in a network share, booting the machine to the network, then accessing the installation program from the share. 

C. Repair Installation - This is used to troubleshoot Windows 7 OS when there is a problem booting up the system. It is called WINRE and Startup REPAIR. Hence, this is not the answer.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is the amount of memory a user is limited to with a 32-bit version of Windows?

A new company policy states that all end-user access to network resources will be controlled based on the users' roles and responsibilities within the organization.
Which of the following security concepts has the company just enabled?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
principle of least privilege - Accounts should have permission to access only the resources they need and no more.

comments.content: But key word is “concept” not actions. The concept of least privilege would enforce the directory permissions.

discussion.content: I think the concept they are using least privilege but will probably use directory permissions to achieve it. Directory permissions is the tool not the method.

The reason why you think B - Least Privilege would be wrong is because the term itself does not seem to match the description.

Something like Role Privilege would make sense because then you would deduce from the name that based on your role (programmer/manager/sales assoc) you would have certain amount of privileges set for you.

Least privilege would assume that someone who has the lowest set of privileges would get these sets of rules even if they are of the same role. A junior programmer would have less access and be more restricted than a senior programmer just cuz.

But hey, welcome to IT, its all about the technical jargon.

comments.content: In addition, the key word in this question is "security concept", this case meaning the principle of least privilege. Even if C said Active directory permissions, id still say B because Active Directory is a specific software and not a "concept" like principle of least privilege is

Directory permissions doesn't mean ACTIVE directory permissions. A directory is like Desktop or Downloads in Windows. The only answer that has to do with ACTIVE directory is least privilege because the term is used for active directory. It means that you are assigned the least privilege necessary to do your job.

OBJ-2.2: Least privilege is the concept and practice of restricting access rights for users, accounts, and computing processes to only those resources absolutely required to perform routine, legitimate activities. Privilege itself refers to the authorization to bypass certain security restraints.
